ygData.subject: Re: How would novelty search best be applied to a virtual creature controller
ygData.msgSnippet: Thanks for your quick response Ken! You ve given me a lot to think about, I just have to ponder the specifics of how to compare behaviours in an objective way

Thanks for your quick response Ken!
You've given me a lot to think about, I=
 just have to ponder the
specifics of how to compare behaviours in an objec=
tive way in this domain.

Heres a linux only version that I was working on =
recently, its really
messy and I'm sure my code can use a LOT of improvemen=
t (I was kind of
learning as I went along). I only wrote the toribash-esque=
 experiment
and a few changes and features added to python-neat. The actual=

python-neat backend is written by Cesar Gomez and is really terrific,
as p=
ython has a certain elegance about it that makes it seem easier to
grasp. 
=

In order to get it to work you need to download the linux version of
Comma=
nd Line Breve:
http://www.spiderland.org/download.php
Then unzip this in th=
e breve_2.7.2/ directory:
http://peter.berrington.googlepages.com/tori.7z

=
To evolve, open a shell and navigate to the breve directory, then call
the =
ToriExp with python, like this:
python tori/toriExp.py
To view the last bes=
t individual, instead type this:
./bin/breve tori/viewlastbest.py

Theres a=
 HUGE amount of parameters for which I have no idea what the
good values ar=
e. The creator of Toribash is giving me a description of
how his game works=
 but is not at all forthcoming with the specific
implementation details; I =
suppose he is reluctant to give away code
for something he makes money on, =
but it's frustrating as his game is
actually very well balanced, allowing s=
ome very nimble and natural
looking acrobatics. Trial and error is probably=
 the only solution at
this stage.

I encourage people to fool around with t=
his; I'm a complete beginner
to programming this kind of stuff and I've got=
 a lot of really
terrible code I'm sure, so please submit any changes that =
you think
would make sense.


--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley=
" <kstanley@...> wrote:
>
> Hi Peter, that's a good question and of course =
learning to control a 
> virtual creature with novelty search is a complica=
ted issue (and an 
> appealing idea as well). 
> 
> First, you have to deal=
 with all the representational and physical 
> issues outside of novelty se=
arch, like how many inputs, how many 
> outputs, and whether the body itsel=
f is not physically flawed in 
> some way (which is possible).  As you are =
experiencing, the 
> inputs/outputs issue can be prohibitive even with feat=
ure 
> selection.  It is also possible that HyperNEAT could be useful 
> be=
cause it does not care about the # inputs or outputs (and can 
> potentiall=
y exploit geometric regularities), but configuring the 
> substrate then be=
comes the challenge.
> 
> Assuming all of that stuff is set up well with wh=
atever system, then 
> novelty search is a potentially winning approach.  Y=
et as you point 
> out there are some big questions there as well.  In fact=
, we are 
> currently trying to provide the best answers to these questions=
 in 
> ongoing research, but some general principles might help for now: 
>=
 
> First, the archive in novelty search does not not need to contain 
> ev=
ery point ever visited.  Therefore, it tends to grow much slower 
> than th=
e #of evaluations.  However, if it is indeed getting too big  
> then it is=
 not unreasonable to collapse some of the archive points, 
> although there=
 is no standard method yet for how that should be 
> done.  But we have rea=
son to believe there will be effective and 
> simple ways to do that.
> 
> =
Second, the issue of one individual looking different just because 
> of a =
phase difference in effectivley the same behavior is 
> complicated.  For c=
ertain phase disaparities, the two individuals 
> won't look all that diffe=
rent, but it is true that at some 
> disparity, they may look very differen=
t.  Yet it is not clear 
> whether that fact is actually problematic to the=
 novelty search or 
> not, because it would simply reward both types of beh=
avior.  It is 
> possible that the phase difference is a result of some use=
ful 
> genotypic change, which could make it a stepping stone to something =

> better.  Or, it is possible that it is superfluous information and 
> si=
mply takes some extra time exploring the area around the phase-
> shifted i=
ndividual.  So it is hard to say a priori whether it is a 
> major concern.=
  We will have better answers to such questions as the 
> technique is furt=
her explored.
> 
> However, I agree that it would be nice to be able to say=
 the two 
> phase-shifted individuals are largely the same if that is indee=
d 
> what you want to say.  And for that, you would need a pattern-
> match=
ing metric to compute behavioral distance, i.e. something more 
> sophisiti=
cated than simple Cartesian distance.  There are certainly 
> such metrics =
available.  However, it's important to recognize that 
> it is not evident =
at this point that ignoring the phase shift is 
> actually better than taki=
ng it into consideration, because taking it 
> into consideration just mean=
s adding more information to the novelty 
> landscape.
> 
> So overall I th=
ink novelty search is a very promising direction to 
> go for such problems=
, but it is still in the realm of research (i.e. 
> there is no existing pr=
ecedent), so it will involve considerable 
> trial and error to get it righ=
t until all these issues are fleshed 
> out more clearly.  Ultimately, thou=
gh, if our hypothesis about 
> novelty vs. fitness is correct, novelty sear=
ch may turn out to be 
> the *only* way to get certain highly complex types=
 of behavior to 
> evolve in some domains, which is a sobering thought.  Bu=
t if it is 
> true, then there is not much to do other than try it.
> 
> ke=
n
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "peterberrington" <peterberrington@> 
>=
 wrote:
> >
> > I've read Ken's latest paper on novelty search and its a 
>=
 fascinating
> > new approach. For the past couple of months I've been work=
ing on
> > virtual creature controllers; specifically I have a ragdoll rig =

> which
> > I've set up in Breve Simulation Environment (available at
> > =
http://spiderland.org )
> > This ragdoll is modelled after the one in Torib=
ash, a free game 
> which
> > uses the open dynamics engine for physics, li=
ke breve. 
> > 
> > So far a lot of the results I've been having discouragi=
ng; as Ken
> > points out early on in his latest paper, trying to make a wa=
lking
> > biped usually results in it falling over perpetually. You can see=
 
> some
> > WIP videos at my youtube page here:
> > http://www.youtube.com=
/user/thehaircrow
> > 
> > Ultimately, I would like to package AI's with th=
e Toribash game so
> > that they are fun to play against in single player- =
I think this 
> goal
> > is attainable despite being difficult.
> > Decepti=
on is a BIG problem here; if my fitness criteria is time
> > integrated dis=
tance from a goal, it encourages the behaviour of the
> > "Tori" balancing =
in a stable configuration forever, rather than
> > walking, which is what I=
'm trying to encourage. As there is 20 
> joints
> > in this rig, I am prov=
iding joint position and velocity information
> > for each joint, as well a=
s a bias, a sine-wave, the x, y, and z
> > components linear velocity in th=
e reference frame of the Tori's 
> head,
> > and finally 3 variables which =
correspond to the vertical, 
> horizontal
> > and forward orientation of th=
e tori's head with respect to world
> > coordinates.  
> > The current expe=
rimental configuration I am started out as a "pure"
> > ragdoll control whe=
re neural net outputs correspond directly joint
> > velocity; a tanh activa=
tion function is used to allow positive and
> > negative joint movement.
> =
> I then remodeled the experiment to perform as in the Toribash game;
> > t=
he net will receive inputs (and effect joint movements) only 
> every 10
> =
> time steps. More importantly, I increased the amount of outputs 
> from
>=
 > 20 (1 per joint) to 40, in order to accomodate the 4 possible joint
> > =
actions which can occur on a turn: holding, relaxing, extending, 
> and
> >=
 flexing. 
> > 
> > Starting with a fully connected net, that gives a stagg=
eringly huge
> > search space with over 1000 connections. Due to the implem=
entation,
> > its prohibitively slow to evolve large nets as the starting n=
et can
> > take up over 600mb of ram on the heap. Realizing this was a bit
=
> > ridiculous, I implemented feature selection and phased pruning.
> > How=
ever, even with this, deception seems to prevent any useful
> > behaviour; =
the Tori will always get stuck in ruts.
> > 
> > 
> > I am using a python i=
mplementation of neat developed by Cesar Gomez
> > under the GPL, which is =
available at http://code.google.com/p/neat-
> python/
> > 
> > This impleme=
ntation is a WIP and I've already done a lot of tests
> > trying to incorpo=
rate the linear genome encoding taken from the 
> EANT
> > method. I've als=
o been trying to incorporate CMA-ES in order to
> > optimize weights but I =
haven't had much success meshing this with 
> the
> > rest of the code yet.=

> > 
> > Later today when I am home I will post my source files for anyone=
 
> who
> > wishes to experiment with virtual creature neuroevolution.
> > =

> > 
> > 
> > FINALLY, my question. The behaviour of a Tori is currently 
=
> represented
> > as a list of 20 base 4 variables multiplied by the amount=
 of time
> > steps the Tori is evaluated for. The novelty search method pro=
posed
> > for the 2d maze navigation is fairly simple; if theres a new endi=
ng
> > point then 
> > we add that point to a list of discovered behaviours=
. This works 
> well
> > (I imagine) because a point isn't a lot of informa=
tion to hold.
> > 
> > What I want to know is how I can compare the behavio=
ur of 2 ragdoll
> > controllers for novelty; is there any compact encoding =
that would
> > work? Since it often takes 25 000 seperate evaluations to ge=
t any
> > useful behaviour out of this right now, theres going to have to b=
e
> > some way to store 20k seperate behaviours in some way that is fast 
>=
 and
> > easy to compare; what if a Tori has identical behaviour to another=
 
> but
> > does things a couple of time steps later instead? Just comparin=
g 
> the
> > two behaviours it would appear that they were 100% unique, yet=
 a 
> human
> > observer would instantly notice the similarity in how they =
act.
> > 
> > Any ideas?
> >
>
